content: The House Reservists Pay Adjustment Act of 2008, also known as the Act, aims to replace lost income for House employees on active duty under involuntary mobilization order. The House Reservists Pay Adjustment Act of 2008 ensures that eligible House of Representatives employees who are also members of a Reserve component of the Armed Forces receive compensation for active duty months. The Chief Administrative Officer of the House of Representatives pays the employee the difference between their regular compensation from the House and their military compensation from the Secretary of Defense. Eligibility is based on being an employee during the active duty month. The employee's regular compensation from the House is adjusted based on their military compensation from the Secretary of Defense, with eligibility tied to being an employee during the active duty month. The Chief Administrative Officer adjusts compensation for House employees who are also Reserve component members based on military pay received, reducing payments by any other income replacement sources. The minimum amount required for payment is $50, and an "active duty month" is defined as a month during which the employee is unable to perform duties due to being on active duty for more than 30 days. Authorization of appropriations is granted for payments under this section, with the effective date applying to active duty months starting after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. Amends rule XXIII of the House of Representatives to allow payments authorized under the House Reservists Pay Adjustment Act of 2008. SEC. 4. Clarifies eligibility of survivors for House gratuity. SEC. 4. CLARIFICATION OF ELIGIBILITY OF SURVIVORS FOR HOUSE GRATUITY. The Legislative Branch Appropriation Act, 1955 is amended to allow the Chief Administrative Officer to pay a gratuity to the widow, widower, or heirs-at-law of a House employee who dies during an active duty month.
